
Two users reused a prime when generating their RSA keys. Intercept the encrypted flag: 3038271514457661632759443951253104953059837054288882085997970453320908720209762817676966862435531156939626521029274618166915086741460985838783153576662497

n=11698942172046905914690418630605533027403168500536175071057690378832314830848625228787084152385868527488269088652645542542585648336087796248365417690017223, n2=10415944150332932250370564698284201669273834122681690204755675239091505704951760091327133385262914608132957035740058679693618715330093731272840380950120869, e=6374509700200990191089597995963880100424137467825401679616535038701786794150745597851224734881664245109026099536144170265753750789950667878456264327530199

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{xyn3k9lg}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 3038271514457661632759443951253104953059837054288882085997970453320908720209762817676966862435531156939626521029274618166915086741460985838783153576662497
vulnerability: shared prime
hint: When two RSA moduli share a common prime, computing GCD(n, n2) can reveal the shared prime factor.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=11698942172046905914690418630605533027403168500536175071057690378832314830848625228787084152385868527488269088652645542542585648336087796248365417690017223, n2=10415944150332932250370564698284201669273834122681690204755675239091505704951760091327133385262914608132957035740058679693618715330093731272840380950120869, e=6374509700200990191089597995963880100424137467825401679616535038701786794150745597851224734881664245109026099536144170265753750789950667878456264327530199
